commit_message:
Remove in-tree periodic job

The periodic job is defined in both openstack/project-config and here.
Remove it here and keep the version in project-config so that we can
update it easily for all projects for train.

Related changes:
* https://review.opendev.org/654571
* https://review.opendev.org/654574

Change-Id: I4408048391dc9a286d8d6ab8f8424a659b1b00ed
(cherry picked from commit 286e54d10a0bec1c01fe97cc1079e3dd1c1d9c22)

commit_message:
Update image links for Ceph.

Updated the links according to the decision here [1].
The convention for images is <imagename>:<tagging>
where <tagging> takes the format <version>-<distro>.

[1]: http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-helm/%23openstack-helm.2019-03-07.log.html#t2019-03-07T17:50:58

Change-Id: I84f8ce731e428f8ef035c008ff615e712c78a1f4

commit_message:
Add Managers<->Systems linkage in sushy-emulator

Redfish BMC is based on three key components: Systems, Managers
and Chassis. While each component has its own properties and
behaviours, however in some situations these components may need
to one another.

This change adds one-to-many style linkage between each of
these three objects.

Change-Id: Ia6cba82125c193f90cea9c67b6110cc4ebf264de

commit_message:
Fix Swift Rate Calculation

* To find the oldest and newest quantities
  for calculating rate, Spark Data Frame
  is converted to a Spark RDD, which makes it
  easy to do a group by and sort. The syntax to pull
  the value from a map column type in an
  RDD is rdd.map_column['key'] which
  is different from dataframe.map_column.key
  which was causing  'dict' object has no attribute
  exception

* Renamed first_attempt_at_spark_test.py to
  test_first_attempt_at_spark, because all the tests
  in that file were not being run.

* Changed the pre transform and transform specs
  which were being used by test_first_attempt_at_spark
  to newer 'dimensions#field_name that was introduced
  in rocky release.

Story: 2005449
Task: 30501

Change-Id: I6adeee54fe261c535372b8f5f3580e7d3261259b

commit_message:
Remove in-tree periodic job

The periodic job is defined in both openstack/project-config and here.
Remove it here and keep the version in project-config so that we can
update it easily for all projects for train.

Related changes:
* https://review.opendev.org/654571
* https://review.opendev.org/654574

Change-Id: I4408048391dc9a286d8d6ab8f8424a659b1b00ed
(cherry picked from commit 286e54d10a0bec1c01fe97cc1079e3dd1c1d9c22)

commit_message:
Auto-index specs and use-cases

This solves the problem of people frequently forgetting to add their
spec or use case to the index.

Change-Id: I70ad8b0ce37027740d3d3a015c70ea2138690d27

commit_message:
Touch the README

The command "git name-rev 05ca984219b8fb6d6fed708061d81d82e8c77a0f"
is segfaulting on this repo, which is causing Gitea to be unable
to serve it.  Gitea is likely running that command because that is
the most recent commit to the README.  Bury it by creating a newer
one which will, one hopes, not cause a segfault in name-rev.

Change-Id: I80ebe63137131e2e0d58947651784f3b682f2ac8

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-17 19:05:37.000000000', 'message': 'libvirt: set device address tag only if setting disk unit

In Pike, we began setting disk unit values manually for the
'virtio-scsi' controller model in order to allow up to 256 devices [1].
We do this by setting the disk unit of the address tag manually for the
guest config. If we do not set the address tag manually, libvirt would
autogenerate it for us.

A problem occurs when a user has a SCSI disk that is a volume or isn't
using the 'virtio-scsi' controller model because we're not guarding our
manual setting of the address tag in the guest config by the disk unit,
in addition to the SCSI bus. This means that for a SCSI volume, we
generate an address tag like '<address type="drive" controller="0"/>'
for any SCSI volume, so a user with more than one device will get the
following error when they try to boot an instance:

  Failed to start libvirt guest: libvirtError: unsupported
    configuration: Found duplicate drive address for disk with target name
    'sda' controller='0' bus='0' target='0' unit='0'

This updates the conditionals to only manually set the address tag if
the bus is SCSI _and_ the disk unit has been specified. Otherwise, let
libvirt autogenerate the address tag and take care of avoiding
collisions.

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1686116

Closes-Bug: #1792077

 Conflicts:
	nova/tests/unit/virt/libvirt/volume/test_volume.py

NOTE(melwitt): Conflict is due to not having change
Ibfa64f18bbd2fb70db7791330ed1a64fe61c1355 in Pike.

Change-Id: Iefab05e84ccc0bf8f15bdbbf515a290d282dbc5d
(cherry picked from commit 48fd81648a7cadf2d147a6beabac067c28b288b0)
(cherry picked from commit 7500c1910cf1cbe16ee48028b67aa919160f44da)
(cherry picked from commit 72fdbb1b045b01d1ce6907066032ffdf5f3fae73)

commit_message:
libvirt: set device address tag only if setting disk unit

In Pike, we began setting disk unit values manually for the
'virtio-scsi' controller model in order to allow up to 256 devices [1].
We do this by setting the disk unit of the address tag manually for the
guest config. If we do not set the address tag manually, libvirt would
autogenerate it for us.

A problem occurs when a user has a SCSI disk that is a volume or isn't
using the 'virtio-scsi' controller model because we're not guarding our
manual setting of the address tag in the guest config by the disk unit,
in addition to the SCSI bus. This means that for a SCSI volume, we
generate an address tag like '<address type="drive" controller="0"/>'
for any SCSI volume, so a user with more than one device will get the
following error when they try to boot an instance:

  Failed to start libvirt guest: libvirtError: unsupported
    configuration: Found duplicate drive address for disk with target name
    'sda' controller='0' bus='0' target='0' unit='0'

This updates the conditionals to only manually set the address tag if
the bus is SCSI _and_ the disk unit has been specified. Otherwise, let
libvirt autogenerate the address tag and take care of avoiding
collisions.

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1686116

Closes-Bug: #1792077

 Conflicts:
     nova/tests/unit/virt/libvirt/volume/test_volume.py

NOTE(melwitt): Conflict is due to not having change
Ibfa64f18bbd2fb70db7791330ed1a64fe61c1355 in Pike.

Change-Id: Iefab05e84ccc0bf8f15bdbbf515a290d282dbc5d
(cherry picked from commit 48fd81648a7cadf2d147a6beabac067c28b288b0)
(cherry picked from commit 7500c1910cf1cbe16ee48028b67aa919160f44da)
(cherry picked from commit 8703282508954596e1d041340878c636693d8f5f)
(cherry picked from commit c8ad9f4e1949ce6fdada565cc6660fbac7f75d6c)

commit_message:
Remove openstack-tox-py35-with-neutron-lib-master

This is a job that runs only on master and it stayed in project-config.
It should not have been imported here as part of python3-first topic,
remove it again.

Change-Id: I2063fba3620cf5f265bb133a9c89f64804887807
(cherry picked from commit e4dcff5e57a62c75359e55d3c6e627227b1f80e6)

rabbitmq chart

commit_message:
[DNM] Test bulk port mac fix

This is a null commit that exists purely to exercise tests, so that we
can see if the fix for bulk port mac addresses works.

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2017-04-04 03:59:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

An example filter would look something like this http://cdn.pasteraw.com/hgtukswxs17hykknf26vy61pyk1xtr3'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2017-04-04 05:02:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Example working filter: [ http://cdn.pasteraw.com/4hwj5sia2886m6vs5fhag4sumulludb ]

Example playbook consuming the filter: [ http://cdn.pasteraw.com/9inyb6a1jwxguyusyuxx9hkhmqyqjxi ]'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2017-04-05 08:31:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

> Example working filter: [ http://cdn.pasteraw.com/4hwj5sia2886m6vs5fhag4sumulludb
 > ]
 > 
 > Example playbook consuming the filter: [ http://cdn.pasteraw.com/9inyb6a1jwxguyusyuxx9hkhmqyqjxi
 > ]

I don't understand why I would chain the lookup and the filter. It would work, like the way I could get a set_fact and implement jinja looping, but I think a lookup should do one thing and doing it well.

I think py_pkgs should be for python packages as distro_pkgs would be for deb/rpm pkgs.

Do you think we should have a reusable python generic directory traversal for those two instead?"}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2017-04-06 01:59:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

> > Example working filter: [ http://cdn.pasteraw.com/4hwj5sia2886m6vs5fhag4sumulludb
 > > ]
 > >
 > > Example playbook consuming the filter: [ http://cdn.pasteraw.com/9inyb6a1jwxguyusyuxx9hkhmqyqjxi
 > > ]
 > 
 > I don't understand why I would chain the lookup and the filter. It
 > would work, like the way I could get a set_fact and implement jinja
 > looping, but I think a lookup should do one thing and doing it
 > well.
 > 
 > I think py_pkgs should be for python packages as distro_pkgs would
 > be for deb/rpm pkgs.
 > 
 > Do you think we should have a reusable python generic directory
 > traversal for those two instead?

Running the existing lookup and using a filter, like the one in my example, is less cycles in terms of loops and and code duplication than the purposed change. If we're hung up on the name of "py_pkgs" then maybe we rename it to "packages_to_install" which covers both py and distro.

Because ansible plugins can't share code like a common python install-ables I'd not be in favor of creating such a structure where two lookups use the same common lib.

We already have a plugin that does this work, does it fast, does it well, and is well curated. It was built for this very purpose and it seems crazy to me to do a similar thing in a different way when we already have the ability to achieve all of the above with nothing more than a simple filter.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2017-04-18 12:24:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

If you're not for loading a separate library, and not for this lookup plugin we are in a deadlock.

The only part I reuse would be https://github.com/openstack/openstack-ansible-plugins/blob/master/lookup/py_pkgs.py#L329-L358, the main call (not used for ansible), and a few vars, so around 30 lines at best on 800+.

Bringing more features to our py_pkg lookup is possible, but I think it's already doing too much. Let's keep our lookups as simple as possible."}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-04-24 16:23:16.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Add list of packages to install lookup

This new lookup makes easy to check into any folder list
(for example /etc/ansible/roles), find in these folder the
variable files for a distribution (given in lookup parameters),
find the system packages to install for this distribution.

In short with one lookup, you get exactly the list of what you
will be installing on your host.

You can blacklist variable names (standard matching) and
package names (regexp matching).

This lookup could technically be replaced by jinja on the
py_pkgs output, but:
- We would then need to build the pkg_blacklist into the
  jinja everytime
- We would need to build the "convenience mapping" into
  the jinja everytime
This makes it simple and re-usable.

Change-Id: I74d498fbe9e61df854aa766b6e3dc84d82f2c6c0

commit_message:
Remove openstack-tox-py35-with-neutron-lib-master

This is a job that runs only on master and it stayed in project-config.
It should not have been imported here as part of python3-first topic,
remove it again.

Change-Id: Id1ddf79100d83f665b62b1ef73ed8689a2afd3bb
(cherry picked from commit 21df6d542b279176dd24d3806033897d123598c6)

commit_message:
Fix Flask config load under WSGI

Fixes Flask config file load as pointed by the `SUSHY_EMULATOR_CONFIG`
environment variable when running under WSGI server. Before this fix,
the above mentioned environment variable was ignored and user config
file not loaded.

Change-Id: I79890bb2db0a40effdb8fa78dab6c0b3ceb9d0f8

[{'created': '2019-04-17 11:07:58.000000000', 'message': 'Make utility install playbook idempotent

To ensure idempotence we do the following:

1. Ensure that the symlinks are only changed if
   they do not yet exist.
2. Switch the openstack client bash completion to
   be a handler which is executed whenever the
   venv changes or the symlinks change.

Change-Id: I6e3ae377c37fb8b72b5ff913154f7763d1691b25
'}]
commit_message:
Make utility install playbook idempotent

To ensure idempotence we do the following:

1. Ensure that the symlinks are only changed if
   they do not yet exist.
2. Switch the openstack client bash completion to
   be a handler which is executed whenever the
   venv changes or the symlinks change.

Change-Id: I6e3ae377c37fb8b72b5ff913154f7763d1691b25

commit_message:
Add cassandra support

Support Cassandra db installation and Cassandra related
configurations for Monasca api and persister services
in devstack. Add Monasca rest API Cassandra plugin for
retrieving metric, dimension, measurement, statistics
and alarms.

Also includes the equivalent of
commit eb78188f97c8576fc39c1dbb7057bddf4fc56113 as the
previous commit 011db48a92a2b... was not compatible.

Depends-On: I4bbe48f8fe550385de6ed3e14120850a8542c7c9
Change-Id: Ie60d668692e1f25f555dda2355f4e513d582736c

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-24 15:10:05.000000000', 'message': 'Fix detection of already initialised lxc storage pool

The related bug was caused because the charm did not detect when
the lxc storage had already been set up using the `lxc storage`
command which is used in the 3.x series, rather than the old way
with the 2.x series.

Also fixes issue on xenial where linux-image-extra-* has been renamed to
linux-modules-extra-* from from -4.4.0-145-generic onwards.  Otherwise,
the install fails on xenial.

Closes-Bug: #1825393
(cherry picked from commit 4bf72620c3cf9cef5905a07132510df2cec5de41)

Change-Id: Ieb8b5c3cfd13b2a601d79fa7a99d29229acc287e
'}]
commit_message:
Fix detection of already initialised lxc storage pool

The related bug was caused because the charm did not detect when
the lxc storage had already been set up using the `lxc storage`
command which is used in the 3.x series, rather than the old way
with the 2.x series.

Also fixes issue on xenial where linux-image-extra-* has been renamed to
linux-modules-extra-* from from -4.4.0-145-generic onwards.  Otherwise,
the install fails on xenial.

Closes-Bug: #1825393
(cherry picked from commit 4bf72620c3cf9cef5905a07132510df2cec5de41)

Change-Id: Ieb8b5c3cfd13b2a601d79fa7a99d29229acc287e

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-24 14:53:11.000000000', 'message': "Fix LP access credentials

In the Great Migration of 2019, the consumer_key name used in the
credentials used by release jobs to update Launchpad bugs was
updated, breaking our connections to LP.

Since switching to a fully new key is non-trivial, let's restore
the old, working, albeit slightly wrong key name.

Change-Id: I71c37d1f77db63d181cb054ba37536f4f3c51aac
"}]
commit_message:
Fix LP access credentials

In the Great Migration of 2019, the consumer_key name used in the
credentials used by release jobs to update Launchpad bugs was
updated, breaking our connections to LP.

Since switching to a fully new key is non-trivial, let's restore
the old, working, albeit slightly wrong key name.

Change-Id: I71c37d1f77db63d181cb054ba37536f4f3c51aac

commit_message:
Fix detection of already initialised lxc storage pool

The related bug was caused because the charm did not detect when
the lxc storage had already been set up using the `lxc storage`
command which is used in the 3.x series, rather than the old way
with the 2.x series.

Also fixes issue on xenial where linux-image-extra-* has been renamed to
linux-modules-extra-* from from -4.4.0-145-generic onwards.  Otherwise,
the install fails on xenial.

Change-Id: If8bdad6f5641ee21fc7860dceeb4c3facbaecc76
Closes-Bug: #1825393

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-01 19:51:37.000000000', 'message': "Fix memcache pool client in monkey-patched environments

First off, this is an ugly hack, but we're dealing with code that
essentially monkey-patches a monkey-patch. You reap what you sow.

Per the linked bug, our connection pool client explodes on python 3
with eventlet monkey-patching in force:

TypeError: object() takes no parameters

This is due to the way __new__ is overridden in the class. We need
to strip arguments from the call before they get to object(), which
doesn't accept args.

Unfortunately, when we're _not_ monkey-patched, adding the new
override implementation fails with:

TypeError: object.__new__(_MemcacheClient) is not safe,
use Client.__new__()

As such, we need different implementations depending on whether we
are monkey-patched or not. This change passes both with and without
monkey-patching and adds a unit test that exposes the bug.

Note that this is a temporary, backportable fix that will ultimately
be replaced by a switch to the pymemcache library which does not
have the threading.local problem being worked around here.

Change-Id: I039dffadeebd0ff4479b9c870c257772c43aba53
Partial-Bug: 1812935
(cherry picked from commit f4a25f642991a7114b86f6eb7d0bac3d599953a6)
"}, {'created': '2019-03-07 19:30:37.000000000', 'message': "Fix memcache pool client in monkey-patched environments

essentially monkey-patches a monkey-patch. You reap what you sow.

Per the linked bug, our connection pool client explodes on python 3
with eventlet monkey-patching in force:

TypeError: object() takes no parameters

This is due to the way __new__ is overridden in the class. We need
to strip arguments from the call before they get to object(), which
doesn't accept args.

Unfortunately, when we're _not_ monkey-patched, adding the new
override implementation fails with:

TypeError: object.__new__(_MemcacheClient) is not safe,
use Client.__new__()

As such, we need different implementations depending on whether we
are monkey-patched or not. This change passes both with and without
monkey-patching and adds a unit test that exposes the bug.

Note that this is a temporary, backportable fix that will ultimately
be replaced by a switch to the pymemcache library which does not
have the threading.local problem being worked around here.

Change-Id: I039dffadeebd0ff4479b9c870c257772c43aba53
Partial-Bug: 1812935
Closes-Bug: 1812672
(cherry picked from commit f4a25f642991a7114b86f6eb7d0bac3d599953a6)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix memcache pool client in monkey-patched environments

First off, this is an ugly hack, but we're dealing with code that
essentially monkey-patches a monkey-patch. You reap what you sow.

Per the linked bug, our connection pool client explodes on python 3
with eventlet monkey-patching in force:

TypeError: object() takes no parameters

This is due to the way __new__ is overridden in the class. We need
to strip arguments from the call before they get to object(), which
doesn't accept args.

Unfortunately, when we're _not_ monkey-patched, adding the new
override implementation fails with:

TypeError: object.__new__(_MemcacheClient) is not safe,
use Client.__new__()

As such, we need different implementations depending on whether we
are monkey-patched or not. This change passes both with and without
monkey-patching and adds a unit test that exposes the bug.

Note that this is a temporary, backportable fix that will ultimately
be replaced by a switch to the pymemcache library which does not
have the threading.local problem being worked around here.

Change-Id: I039dffadeebd0ff4479b9c870c257772c43aba53
Partial-Bug: 1812935
Closes-Bug: 1812672
(cherry picked from commit f4a25f642991a7114b86f6eb7d0bac3d599953a6)

[{'created': '2018-09-05 00:13:14.000000000', 'message': 'Add exact match aggregate image properties matcher/filter

This filter is a variant of the AggregateImagePropertiesIsolation
but is distinct enough that it should likely be its own thing.

The reasoning behind it is that the existing filter is a little
to tolerant of missing image properties (when you really want it
to match exactly) and to setup your aggregates and images with that
filter is very tedious, fragile, and error prone.

So instead of that filter, this filter uses some of the same concepts
but is less tolerant of missing image properties (for example when
you setup a windows only hypervisor set you do not want other images
with various other properties to end up there).

Co-author: Elancheran Subramanian <esubramanian@godaddy.com>

Change-Id: I9ba17489b914edeb7e882380d98ac497ddc0b383

commit_message:
Add exact match aggregate image properties matcher/filter

This filter is a variant of the AggregateImagePropertiesIsolation
but is distinct enough that it should likely be its own thing.

The reasoning behind it is that the existing filter is a little
to tolerant of missing image properties (when you really want it
to match exactly) and to setup your aggregates and images with that
filter is very tedious, fragile, and error prone.

So instead of that filter, this filter uses some of the same concepts
but is less tolerant of missing image properties (for example when
you setup a windows only hypervisor set you do not want other images
with various other properties to end up there).

Co-author: Elancheran Subramanian <esubramanian@godaddy.com>

Change-Id: I9ba17489b914edeb7e882380d98ac497ddc0b383

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-08-31 18:48:52.000000000', 'message': 'Add apply_cells to nova-manage

This adds a new apply_cells method to the nova-manage commands that
reads in a specification file (json or yaml) and sets up the
configurations based on the specifications within the file. This
feature matches cell_mappings to specifications based on its name and
will "make-it-so" for cell_mappings by:
* create_cell (spec exists with a name not already in cell_mappings),
* update_cell (spec and mapping exist, but have different values),
* delete_cell (spec file does not have a matching cell by name).

There is a --dry-run argument that can be used to see what would change
without actually performing any modifications.

This should allow automated systems that want to source control (git or
inventory generated) how their cells are setup and managed.

Change-Id: I7a60a02637d85f576d4be6d9ea8a5e2a01360d0c

commit_message:
Add apply_cells to nova-manage

This adds a new apply_cells method to the nova-manage commands that
reads in a specification file (json or yaml) and sets up the
configurations based on the specifications within the file. This
feature matches cell_mappings to specifications based on its name and
will "make-it-so" for cell_mappings by:
* create_cell (spec exists with a name not already in cell_mappings),
* update_cell (spec and mapping exist, but have different values),
* delete_cell (spec file does not have a matching cell by name).

There is a --dry-run argument that can be used to see what would change
without actually performing any modifications.

This should allow automated systems that want to source control (git or
inventory generated) how their cells are setup and managed.

Change-Id: I7a60a02637d85f576d4be6d9ea8a5e2a01360d0c

commit_message:
Dropping the py35 testing

All the integration testing has been moved to
Bionic now[1] and py3.5 is not tested runtime for
Train or stable/stein[2].

As per below ML thread, we are good to drop the py35
testing now:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/005097.html

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/004647.html
[2]
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/stein.html
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/train.html

commit_message:
Dropping the py35 testing

All the integration testing has been moved to
Bionic now[1] and py3.5 is not tested runtime for
Train or stable/stein[2].

As per below ML thread, we are good to drop the py35
testing now:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/005097.html

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/004647.html
[2]
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/stein.html
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/train.html

Change-Id: I0d3d40f8ac10f5b765141939cd3424332e1d4138

commit_message:
Move release version to different file

Without this patch, the version is included in a bigger variable
file, and is marginally harder to automate.

This fixes the problem by separating the version to a new file,
as it was decided during the PTG.

Change-Id: I78bd1ff56440da6d8a8fda91ab2e9fb9d106d208

subject: [WIP] Ensure python3-pkg-resources is installed
messages:
[{'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-05-07 16:03:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-05-07 16:08:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Markos, opinion?

What's the native python stack implementation on SUSE? python3?"}, {'account_id': 19298, 'date': '2018-05-07 16:14:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 23163, 'date': '2018-05-08 07:46:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I think we should switch to python2 on 16.04. revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-07 16:03:40.000000000', 'message': "[WIP] Ensure python3-pkg-resources is installed

Makes the requirement to install python3-pkg-resources explicit,
to fix circular dependencies.

Note:
I am not sure we should do this, but instead clean the python3
from ubuntu 16.04, and start fresh with ubuntu 18.04, as 18.04 is
now out. Or if we wholly switch to python3 later. But consistency
is good, and being dual stack doesn't seem to help.

Change-Id: I5b682dff891349334f1161de7cfa09f484701219
"}, {'created': '2018-08-06 13:29:59.000000000', 'message': "[WIP] Ensure python3-pkg-resources is installed

to fix circular dependencies.

Note:
I am not sure we should do this, but instead clean the python3
from ubuntu 16.04, and start fresh with ubuntu 18.04, as 18.04 is
now out. Or if we wholly switch to python3 later. But consistency
is good, and being dual stack doesn't seem to help.

Change-Id: I5b682dff891349334f1161de7cfa09f484701219
"}]
commit_message:
[WIP] Ensure python3-pkg-resources is installed

Makes the requirement to install python3-pkg-resources explicit,
to fix circular dependencies.

Note:
I am not sure we should do this, but instead clean the python3
from ubuntu 16.04, and start fresh with ubuntu 18.04, as 18.04 is
now out. Or if we wholly switch to python3 later. But consistency
is good, and being dual stack doesn't seem to help.

Change-Id: I5b682dff891349334f1161de7cfa09f484701219

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-12 12:57:16.000000000', 'message': 'Make docs be container agnostic

If the documentation has a reference of lxc container, that
documentation wouldn't apply on nspawn world. This changes
the references to use a more common "containers-create",
and "containers-destroy".

At the same time, to avoid repeating ourselves, we modify the
"containers-deploy" mechanism to call the newly created
"containers-create".

Change-Id: Icd6a64968a0b2d606f08fcb94495413ca91b188e

commit_message:
Make docs be container agnostic

If the documentation has a reference of lxc container, that
documentation wouldn't apply on nspawn world. This changes
the references to use a more common "containers-create",
and "containers-destroy".

At the same time, to avoid repeating ourselves, we modify the
"containers-deploy" mechanism to call the newly created
"containers-create".

Change-Id: Icd6a64968a0b2d606f08fcb94495413ca91b188e

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-05 17:07:48.000000000', 'message': '[WIP] "Higher performance" memcached driver

According to keystone sample configuration, the
oslo_cache.memcache_pool should be used for eventlet-based
or highly threaded servers [1], while
dogpile.cache.memcached should be used for low thread servers
[2]. Because we don't use redis, memcached should be good
enough for us.

My test don't show any performance difference when two
backends servers are used and one is down: Both settings
are slow: They both query the dead server.
Performance optimizations are probably elsewhere when
memcached servers are online (proper object
pooling?)

[1]: https://github.com/openstack/keystone/blob/775deeae0c99bd98595890ef9840dce9c6d917d8/etc/keystone.conf.sample#L501
[2]: https://github.com/openstack/keystone/blob/775deeae0c99bd98595890ef9840dce9c6d917d8/etc/keystone.conf.sample#L502

Change-Id: Ice6eabd4392c2b35f84289d1065acf76dd05a7b7

[2]. Because we don't use redis, memcached should be good
enough for us.

My test don't show any performance difference when two

are slow: They both query the dead server.
Performance optimizations are probably elsewhere when
memcached servers are online (proper object
pooling).

According to kmalloc:
"the memcache pool uses a fixed number of connections
 instead of a one-per-request model. It was designed to
 help in the case of eventlet, however, it can cause more
 latency/blocking on getting data because the pool has a
 fixed size."


[1]: https://github.com/openstack/keystone/blob/775deeae0c99bd98595890ef9840dce9c6d917d8/etc/keystone.conf.sample#L501
[2]: https://github.com/openstack/keystone/blob/775deeae0c99bd98595890ef9840dce9c6d917d8/etc/keystone.conf.sample#L502

Change-Id: Ice6eabd4392c2b35f84289d1065acf76dd05a7b7
'}]
commit_message:
[WIP] "Higher performance" memcached driver

According to keystone sample configuration, the
oslo_cache.memcache_pool should be used for eventlet-based
or highly threaded servers [1], while
dogpile.cache.memcached should be used for low thread servers
[2]. Because we don't use redis, memcached should be good
enough for us.

My test don't show any performance difference when two
backends servers are used and one is down: Both settings
are slow: They both query the dead server.
Performance optimizations are probably elsewhere when
memcached servers are online (proper object
pooling).

According to kmalloc:
"the memcache pool uses a fixed number of connections
 instead of a one-per-request model. It was designed to
 help in the case of eventlet, however, it can cause more
 latency/blocking on getting data because the pool has a
 fixed size."


[1]: https://github.com/openstack/keystone/blob/775deeae0c99bd98595890ef9840dce9c6d917d8/etc/keystone.conf.sample#L501
[2]: https://github.com/openstack/keystone/blob/775deeae0c99bd98595890ef9840dce9c6d917d8/etc/keystone.conf.sample#L502

Change-Id: Ice6eabd4392c2b35f84289d1065acf76dd05a7b7

We should probably add some functional testing to see if it's using the clustering in an appropriate way.

Waiting for reviews to get opinion on how we should do that."}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2018-02-01 16:10:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

> We should probably add some functional testing to see if it's using

 >

Ideally you'd have to make sure traffic is getting routed to each node in the memcache pool, right?"}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-02-01 16:14:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> (1 comment)
 > 
 > > We should probably add some functional testing to see if it's
 > using
 > > the clustering in an appropriate way.
 > >
 > > Waiting for reviews to get opinion on how we should do that.
 > 
 > Ideally you'd have to make sure traffic is getting routed to each
 > node in the memcache pool, right?

I am not sure to understand how to actually test that. Traffic is routed makes me think of network routing, which is not what we are looking for. And if the configuration is pointing to multiple nodes, we need to make sure the cache is really hit. I guess that's what you meant, but I am not sure how to check the cache hit for all the servers.

Maybe we could do a long running check to see if there are connections done to all containers on the memcached port. Or alternatively, maybe check if there is cache hit/miss access log."}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-02-01 16:15:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

 > 
 > Maybe we could do a long running check to see if there are
 > connections done to all containers on the memcached port. Or
 > alternatively, maybe check if there is cache hit/miss access log.

Right - that's what I meant. I agree though, that is going to be hard to test for and I'm not sure how you would. Maybe checking connections is the best way to do it so long as we can assert it fails?"}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-02-05 12:57:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Published edit on patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-02-05 12:57:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow-1

Need to figure out:
- If I need to do it in gates (probably not, voting check is enough)
- if it's normal that the tests only connects to first node of the pool with this backend
- why the conditionals seem to fail."}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-02-12 07:52:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14: Published edit on patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-02-12 07:53:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-02-12 07:54:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15: Published edit on patch set 14.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-02-12 07:54:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2018-02-12 10:51:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15:

FYI it is normal for the first pool host to be used only - all the drivers I've seen will only connect to the second one in the pool if the first one fails, there is no 'clustering' function that ensures that all pool nodes have the same cache either... if the first node goes down, the cache is lost and has to be rebuilt on the second one."}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-02-12 12:56:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15:

> FYI it is normal for the first pool host to be used only - all the
 > drivers I've seen will only connect to the second one in the pool
 > if the first one fails, there is no 'clustering' function that
 > ensures that all pool nodes have the same cache either... if the
 > first node goes down, the cache is lost and has to be rebuilt on
 > the second one.

It's two different things to consider usage and connections.

I expected the connections to be done in a meshed way, but data will be only active in one node. I didn't expected shared data, while it could technically be implemented by the connector."}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-02-12 12:57:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15:

Should I mention that I expected this failure to happen, I just wanted to see it is well tested for now.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-02-12 12:57:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16: Patch Set 15 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2018-02-12 13:06:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 16:

As far as I know, the connections are only opened to the second server when needed. There's no purpose in holding open a TCP connection to anything except the primary node."}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-02-12 15:47:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 16: Workflow-1 Code-Review-2

I don't see a point of adding this functional testing then.

Except maybe if I cut memcached in the process and see how the system reacts. But I am not sure this is important, rn."}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2018-02-12 15:59:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 16:

Yep, other than ensuring that the pool config is properly laid out - there's not really much to test and I don't think it's really worth the hassle.

What might be nice is to figure out a way to actually verify that keystone is caching because we got into the broken cache configuration state because there was no way of validating it.

I wonder if the keystone crew could implement something like that into their tempest unit tests."}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-02-13 13:28:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 16:

> Yep, other than ensuring that the pool config is properly laid out
 > - there's not really much to test and I don't think it's really
 > worth the hassle.
 > 
 > What might be nice is to figure out a way to actually verify that
 > keystone is caching because we got into the broken cache
 > configuration state because there was no way of validating it.
 > 
 > I wonder if the keystone crew could implement something like that
 > into their tempest unit tests.

I propose we discuss this at the PTG."}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-04-24 14:33:24.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Test keystone with a memcached pool

On top of testing keystone with just one server, we should
test it with a pool of nodes, to see how it behaves.

Depends-On: I1be8ad46c29c1719c7fadd4c91aeea21923d5681
Depends-On: I85ebce8b41dd440e1866a08aa1329b3df798c04f
Change-Id: If4cfbd6b9729f21f6f4a56ee7fe9a59c9dab6474

commit_message:
Refactor post-run

This simplifies post-run plays. Deployers wanting to gather
logs can also do it on their machine by simply using the shell
scripts in zuul.d/playbooks.

Because post-run was defined multiple times but were inheriting
from the same job (osh-infra-functional), the post-run definition
was moved to the base job.

Finally the gathering of the logs is only done once, avoiding
ssh issues.

The previous log gathering cannot be removed until all the other
jobs using the scripts are converted.

Change-Id: I5305ef03f817f84f2b8993c04146d207b0b357e6

commit_message:
Use Ceph helpers from ``charms.openstack``

The Ceph relation adapter and keyring helper code was moved to
``charms.openstack`` as part of development of the
``ceph-rbd-mirror`` charm.

Port the Gnocchi charm to re-use this code.

Depends-On: If1d645f4708e27b724f93cac0e14431137c885d7
Depends-On: I97b4c30dabfcf65ec3fb876c2a09a44172be85e7
Change-Id: If0da7f1efcfa6b61aa210edcd76e9c3392e0e8e9

messages: [{'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-04-16 04:43:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-04-16 04:50:34.000000000', 'content': 'Topic set to dropping-py35-testing'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2019-04-16 13:29:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 9796, 'date': '2019-04-24 12:46:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-16 04:43:59.000000000', 'message': 'Dropping the py35 testing

All the integration testing has been moved to
Bionic now[1] and py3.5 is not tested runtime for
Train or stable/stein[2].

As per below ML thread, we are good to drop the py35
testing now:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/005097.html

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/004647.html
[2]
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/stein.html
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/train.html

Change-Id: Ib38da77120fd0392984388350bb785eae5893c06

commit_message:
Dropping the py35 testing

All the integration testing has been moved to
Bionic now[1] and py3.5 is not tested runtime for
Train or stable/stein[2].

As per below ML thread, we are good to drop the py35
testing now:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/005097.html

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/004647.html
[2]
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/stein.html
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/train.html

Change-Id: Ib38da77120fd0392984388350bb785eae5893c06

[{'created': '2019-02-19 17:54:27.000000000', 'message': 'Refactor _heal_allocations_for_instance to make place for port healing

The current structur of _heal_allocations_for_instance makes it hard to
add the port related allocation to process as that needs to be added
both if the allocation does not exists at all or when only the user_id
and project_id is missing or when only the ports needs healing.

So this patch reorganize the logic to allow adding the port healing
easier in later patch

commit_message:
Refactor _heal_allocations_for_instance to make place for port healing

Add a bit of extra strucutre so that port healing can be easier later

Related-Bug: #1819923

[{'created': '2019-04-19 13:55:28.000000000', 'message': "Fix prometheus metrics gathering in postrun job

This adds '|| true' to the curl command for gathering metrics from
prometheus exporters in the postrun job. After the move to
minikube for single node jobs, the headless services for the
kubernetes components no longer work as intended. The addition of
'|| true' allows the post run job to continue through the list
of services tied to the prometheus exporters without the task
failing outright

Change-Id: I56f0f56b799c3df9b2bd66a2c2044d71473606e3
"}, {'created': '2019-04-22 12:02:11.000000000', 'message': "Fix prometheus metrics gathering in postrun job

"}]
commit_message:
Fix prometheus metrics gathering in postrun job

This adds '|| true' to the curl command for gathering metrics from
prometheus exporters in the postrun job. After the move to
minikube for single node jobs, the headless services for the
kubernetes components no longer work as intended. The addition of
'|| true' allows the post run job to continue through the list
of services tied to the prometheus exporters without the task
failing outright

Change-Id: I56f0f56b799c3df9b2bd66a2c2044d71473606e3

commit_message:
Filters fetching backups for incremental backup

In create method of backup, while doing an incremental backup all
existing backup entries get fetched from DB to search for the one
to use in incremental.

Now, only required one would be fetched after adding sort_keys='created_at'
and limit=1.

Change-Id: I4ca4fd0dc3c294ebead069c5bb93e869b417439e
Closes-Bug: 1696715

commit_message:
Rehome provider_network_attribute_updates_supported to API definition

Rehomed provider_network_attribute_updates_supported to
plugins.ml2.api.MechanismDriver, in order to be inherited in other
mechanism drivers.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/651175/
Related-Bug: #1823865

Change-Id: Ie622d94fe9559a6c7d4200e4da2e2c568629908e

commit_message:
Use branched version of neutron-tempest-plugin job

With the recent changes from [0] the job definition from master only
works with master devstack, so we need to use the branched definition of
it instead.

[0] https://review.opendev.org/648904

Change-Id: Ie9e2f09be320882fd4b6cb6820be0abee048f054

commit_message:
Fix docs bug link to go to storyboard rather than launchpad

This fixes the docs bug link generation for the normal docs
and release notes docs.

The requirement on openstackdocstheme is bumped to 1.23.2 to
pick up fix I2ed164b9b0badade702c50543ac1a5eea4d1867b.

Change-Id: I89711a391ee0fb7e40c1fbf83f950e2b582358d9
Story: #2005467
Task: #30546

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-22 13:45:32.000000000', 'message': 'Fix {min|max}_version in ironic Adapter setup

Change If625411f40be0ba642baeb02950f568f43673655 introduced
nova.utils.get_ksa_adapter, which accepts min_version and max_version
kwargs to be passed through to the ksa Adapter constructor. These are
supposed to represent minimum and maximum *major* API versions,
min_version was erroneously set to *microversions* when setting up the
Adapter for ironicclient. This commit changes it to a major version.
(Microversion negotiation is done within ironicclient itself.)

Also, this bug went latent for several releases because a) it only seems
to be triggered when region_name is given in the conf; but also b)
ironicclient has code to discover a reasonable endpoint if passed None.
So this change also adds a warning log if we try and fail to discover
the endpoint via ksa.

Change-Id: I34a3f8d4a496217eb01790e2d124111625bf5f85
Closes-Bug: #1825583
'}, {'created': '2019-04-22 16:41:50.000000000', 'message': 'Fix {min|max}_version in ironic Adapter setup

Change If625411f40be0ba642baeb02950f568f43673655 introduced
nova.utils.get_ksa_adapter, which accepts min_version and max_version
kwargs to be passed through to the ksa Adapter constructor. These are
supposed to represent minimum and maximum *major* API versions,
min_version was erroneously set to *microversions* when setting up the
Adapter for ironicclient. This commit changes it to a major version.
(Microversion negotiation is done within ironicclient itself.)

Also, this bug went latent for several releases because a) it only seems
to be triggered when region_name is given in the conf; but also b)
ironicclient has code to discover a reasonable endpoint if passed None.
So this change also adds a warning log if we try and fail to discover
the endpoint via ksa.

Change-Id: I34a3f8d4a496217eb01790e2d124111625bf5f85
Closes-Bug: #1825583
'}]
commit_message:
Fix {min|max}_version in ironic Adapter setup

Change If625411f40be0ba642baeb02950f568f43673655 introduced
nova.utils.get_ksa_adapter, which accepts min_version and max_version
kwargs to be passed through to the ksa Adapter constructor. These are
supposed to represent minimum and maximum *major* API versions,
min_version was erroneously set to *microversions* when setting up the
Adapter for ironicclient. This commit changes it to a major version.
(Microversion negotiation is done within ironicclient itself.)

Also, this bug went latent for several releases because a) it only seems
to be triggered when region_name is given in the conf; but also b)
ironicclient has code to discover a reasonable endpoint if passed None.
So this change also adds a warning log if we try and fail to discover
the endpoint via ksa.

Change-Id: I34a3f8d4a496217eb01790e2d124111625bf5f85
Closes-Bug: #1825583

commit_message:
Ansible module: fix clean error handling

It should not be up to the driver to handle the error. The error should
reach the manager. Moreover, handling the error in the driver and
returning nothing caused the manager to consider the step done and go to
the next one instead of interrupting the cleaning workflow

Change-Id: I3825838b5507bc735d983466aa3cac0edd4dfaca
Story: #2005357
Task: #30315
(cherry picked from commit df5261bb349dd56ac88876e14779d244bdc0beb3)

[{'created': '2019-04-24 01:14:01.000000000', 'message': "Don't persist _nova_check_type flag in database

The rebuild flag, set in RequestSpec.scheduler_hints and keyed by
'_nova_check_type' could be accidentally persisted later via
request_spec.save() operation.

To prevent us from reading the persisted data wrongly and from
persisting it, this patch changes the DB interface functions in the
request spec to ignore the data keyed by the '_nova_check_type' in
the RequestSpec.scheduler_hints for both cases, reading and writing.

Note that the writing DB path added in this patch could be reverted
in the future once we have no case to use '_nova_check_type'
refactoring the rebuild path not to rely on the scheduler hint hack.

Change-Id: If4fc45f774b0034d56e70d79f17b9a6b197815dc
Closes-Bug: #1823369
"}, {'created': '2019-04-24 07:56:19.000000000', 'message': "Don't persist _nova_check_type flag in database

'_nova_check_type' could be accidentally persisted later via

To prevent us from reading the persisted data wrongly and from

request spec to ignore the data keyed by the '_nova_check_type' in
the RequestSpec.scheduler_hints for both cases, reading and writing.

Note that this could partially be reverted in the future once we have
no case to use '_nova_check_type' refactoring the rebuild path not to

Change-Id: If4fc45f774b0034d56e70d79f17b9a6b197815dc
Closes-Bug: #1823369
"}]
commit_message:
Don't persist _nova_check_type flag in database

The rebuild flag, set in RequestSpec.scheduler_hints and keyed by
'_nova_check_type' could be accidentally persisted later via
request_spec.save() operation.

To prevent us from reading the persisted data wrongly and from
persisting it, this patch changes the DB interface functions in the
request spec to ignore the data keyed by the '_nova_check_type' in
the RequestSpec.scheduler_hints for both cases, reading and writing.

Note that this could partially be reverted in the future once we have
no case to use '_nova_check_type' refactoring the rebuild path not to
rely on the scheduler hint hack.

Change-Id: If4fc45f774b0034d56e70d79f17b9a6b197815dc
Closes-Bug: #1823369

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-18 13:42:57.000000000', 'message': "Fix keepalived VIP monitoring script

Currently keepalived monitors VIPs by running some shell commands
that target HAProxy. The generated shell command is invalid, which
makes keepalived log errors.

Tue Apr 16 11:55:57 2019:    Command = '/usr/bin/test' '-S' '/var/lib/haproxy/stats' '&&' 'echo' 'show'
Tue Apr 16 11:55:57 2019: Script `haproxy` now returning 2
Tue Apr 16 11:55:57 2019: VRRP_Script(haproxy) failed (exited with status 2)

Fix quoting and invoke /bin/sh explicitely to fix the error:

Thu Apr 18 13:16:35 2019:    Command = '/usr/bin/sh' '-c' 'test -S /var/lib/haproxy/stats && echo show info | socat /var/lib/haproxy/stats stdio'
Thu Apr 18 13:16:35 2019: VRRP_Script(haproxy) succeeded

Change-Id: I5a757f88963270e77c8ec411cd292a30f89c6bc0
Closes-Bug: #1825366
"}, {'created': '2019-04-18 17:47:14.000000000', 'message': "Fix keepalived VIP monitoring script

Currently keepalived monitors VIPs by running some shell commands
that target HAProxy. The generated shell command is invalid, which
makes keepalived log errors.

Tue Apr 16 11:55:57 2019:    Command = '/usr/bin/test' '-S' '/var/lib/haproxy/stats' '&&' 'echo' 'show'
Tue Apr 16 11:55:57 2019: Script `haproxy` now returning 2
Tue Apr 16 11:55:57 2019: VRRP_Script(haproxy) failed (exited with status 2)

Fix quoting and invoke /bin/sh explicitely to fix the error:

Thu Apr 18 13:16:35 2019:    Command = '/usr/bin/sh' '-c' 'test -S /var/lib/haproxy/stats && echo show info | socat /var/lib/haproxy/stats stdio'
Thu Apr 18 13:16:35 2019: VRRP_Script(haproxy) succeeded

Change-Id: I5a757f88963270e77c8ec411cd292a30f89c6bc0
Closes-Bug: #1825366
"}]
commit_message:
Fix keepalived VIP monitoring script

Currently keepalived monitors VIPs by running some shell commands
that target HAProxy. The generated shell command is invalid, which
makes keepalived log errors.

Tue Apr 16 11:55:57 2019:    Command = '/usr/bin/test' '-S' '/var/lib/haproxy/stats' '&&' 'echo' 'show'
Tue Apr 16 11:55:57 2019: Script `haproxy` now returning 2
Tue Apr 16 11:55:57 2019: VRRP_Script(haproxy) failed (exited with status 2)

Fix quoting and invoke /bin/sh explicitely to fix the error:

Thu Apr 18 13:16:35 2019:    Command = '/usr/bin/sh' '-c' 'test -S /var/lib/haproxy/stats && echo show info | socat /var/lib/haproxy/stats stdio'
Thu Apr 18 13:16:35 2019: VRRP_Script(haproxy) succeeded

Change-Id: I5a757f88963270e77c8ec411cd292a30f89c6bc0
Closes-Bug: #1825366

commit_message:
Remove Pike jobs and make Queens non-voting

Now that Stein is out and Pike has entered extended maintenance,
remove the Pike jobs and make Queens non-voting in preparation for
adding Stein jobs (will be done separately when the gate stabilizes).

Change-Id: Ie0f0b93f66d059d02c6d551e6f2f847460845a57

Our feature delivery planning process revolves around specs and
we rarely use blueprints anymore.  Remove reference to blueprints
from the documentation.

[{'created': '2019-04-24 11:47:18.000000000', 'message': 'Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/stein

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/stein branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I3d9483cfb50f11c1c32f5a5bc4ae984e2e6bd3f6
'}]
commit_message:
Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/stein

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/stein branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I3d9483cfb50f11c1c32f5a5bc4ae984e2e6bd3f6

commit_message:
Dropping the py35 testing

All the integration testing has been moved to
Bionic now[1] and py3.5 is not tested runtime for
Train or stable/stein[2].

As per below ML thread, we are good to drop the py35
testing now:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/005097.html

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/004647.html
[2]
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/stein.html
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/train.html

Change-Id: I644b37128f70a88debc484a4d57c1c28bb6fde8f

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-17 12:27:27.000000000', 'message': 'Load configfs kernel module for iscsid

The configfs kernel module is not mounted by default in Ubuntu 16.04,
leading to the iscsid container failing to start because it bind mounts
/sys/kernel/config. The issue does not apply to Ubuntu 18.04, or other
distros (AFAIK), which load configfs by default.

This change loads the configfs module when the iscsid container is in
use.

Change-Id: I5b521ddca24b919658d2664ede2d878507d6d106
Closes-Bug: #1631072
(cherry picked from commit 5753a569c7e0ca7f352ebcaeb2386597493bf2b0)
'}]
commit_message:
Load configfs kernel module for iscsid

The configfs kernel module is not mounted by default in Ubuntu 16.04,
leading to the iscsid container failing to start because it bind mounts
/sys/kernel/config. The issue does not apply to Ubuntu 18.04, or other
distros (AFAIK), which load configfs by default.

This change loads the configfs module when the iscsid container is in
use.

Change-Id: I5b521ddca24b919658d2664ede2d878507d6d106
Closes-Bug: #1631072
(cherry picked from commit 5753a569c7e0ca7f352ebcaeb2386597493bf2b0)

commit_message:
Move config option definition

The 'move_disks_on_cold_migration' config option is currently
defined in migrationops.py instead of conf.py, for which reason
it's not included in the generated documentation.

This simple change will move it next to the rest of compute-hyperv
config options. While at it, we're adding a help string.

Change-Id: I762156dea8d32bdc13716b88821ed7495e705607

commit_message:
Uses neutron_lib's rpc module

The module neutron.common.rpc has been deprecated and removed in favor of
neutron_lib.rpc.

neutron_lib.rpc has been introduced in neutron-lib==1.18.0.

Change-Id: Iea1db96069959aa8c1fd8c88ee2c39b947975723

Seems safe to backport.'}, {'account_id': 5202, 'date': '2019-04-23 11:43:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

Thanks Alfredo!'}, {'account_id': 16312, 'date': '2019-04-24 07:28:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-17 16:29:26.000000000', 'message': "Do not include ETag when puting manifest in chunked uploads

While testing glance with Ceph Rados Gateway using latest Ceph release
(Nautilus), i've found that glance fails to upload the manifest using
dynamic large objects mode because of the value used in ETag request.

This issue has been reported to Ceph as it seems related to some recent
change in radosgw code [1].

However, checking at the upload workflow used by glance and comparing
to Swift documentation [2], I wonder if adding the etag is actually
providing any value. In the Swift the ETag header is used to validate
integrity when uploading chunks, not the manifest while glance is doing
exactly the oposite, not sending the etag in the chunks (I guess to
avoid checksuming big images, which makes sense to me) and sending it
when puting the manifest.

This patch is removing the etag header when sending the PUT request for
the manifest in chunked uploads.

[1] https://tracker.ceph.com/issues/39160
[2] https://docs.openstack.org/swift/latest/api/large_objects.html#dynamic-large-objects

Closes-bug: #1824533
Change-Id: I0b563dfcdc30026669fb089c82db8c3df7edc808
(cherry picked from commit ed356fc6b46e133899e1bf1c54df239536ea78b9)
"}]
commit_message:
Do not include ETag when puting manifest in chunked uploads

While testing glance with Ceph Rados Gateway using latest Ceph release
(Nautilus), i've found that glance fails to upload the manifest using
dynamic large objects mode because of the value used in ETag request.

This issue has been reported to Ceph as it seems related to some recent
change in radosgw code [1].

However, checking at the upload workflow used by glance and comparing
to Swift documentation [2], I wonder if adding the etag is actually
providing any value. In the Swift the ETag header is used to validate
integrity when uploading chunks, not the manifest while glance is doing
exactly the oposite, not sending the etag in the chunks (I guess to
avoid checksuming big images, which makes sense to me) and sending it
when puting the manifest.

This patch is removing the etag header when sending the PUT request for
the manifest in chunked uploads.

[1] https://tracker.ceph.com/issues/39160
[2] https://docs.openstack.org/swift/latest/api/large_objects.html#dynamic-large-objects

Closes-bug: #1824533
Change-Id: I0b563dfcdc30026669fb089c82db8c3df7edc808
(cherry picked from commit ed356fc6b46e133899e1bf1c54df239536ea78b9)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-17 14:42:48.000000000', 'message': 'Make the JSON RPC server work with both IPv4 and IPv6

Binding to 0.0.0.0 by default results in inability to work with IPv6,
which is a probable cause of Bifrost gate failures on some nodepool
providers. Using :: solves it.

Change-Id: Ic5c4c9b541c826ccf3025877f7c829fd34d0be6e
'}]
commit_message:
Make the JSON RPC server work with both IPv4 and IPv6

Binding to 0.0.0.0 by default results in inability to work with IPv6,
which is a probable cause of Bifrost gate failures on some nodepool
providers. Using :: solves it.

Change-Id: Ic5c4c9b541c826ccf3025877f7c829fd34d0be6e

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-01 06:54:43.000000000', 'message': "Add support for text ports on Network Policy Spec

This commit adds support for Network Policies that define ports with text
in the ingress or egress section. It checks if the containers
in pods have their ports with the same name as the port defined in the
Network Policy. In the case when the policy is applied over a namespace,
the pods in that namespace have their containers checked and if matched
a Security Group rule with a 'remote_ip_prefix' pointing to that pod is
created.

Change-Id: If1eddc3e6cc4884ca53e81e4f87b5fae80fed70e
Closes-Bug: 1818983
"}, {'created': '2019-04-01 07:53:15.000000000', 'message': "Add support for text ports on Network Policy Spec

in the ingress or egress section. It checks if the containers
in pods have their ports with the same name as the port defined in the
Network Policy. In the case when the policy is applied over a namespace,
the pods in that namespace have their containers checked and if matched
a Security Group rule with a 'remote_ip_prefix' pointing to that pod is
created.

Change-Id: If1eddc3e6cc4884ca53e81e4f87b5fae80fed70e
Closes-Bug: 1818983

This commit adds support for Network Policies that define ports with text
in the ingress or egress section. It checks if the containers
in pods have their ports with the same name as the port defined in the
Network Policy. In the case when the policy is applied over a namespace,
the pods in that namespace have their containers checked and if matched
a Security Group rule with a 'remote_ip_prefix' pointing to that pod is

Change-Id: If1eddc3e6cc4884ca53e81e4f87b5fae80fed70e
Closes-Bug: 1818983
"}, {'created': '2019-04-04 20:34:50.000000000', 'message': "Add support for text ports on Network Policy Spec

This commit adds support for Network Policies that define ports
with text in the ingress or egress section. It checks if the containers
in pods have their ports with the same name as the port defined in the
Network Policy. In the case when a policy restricts traffic
to/from namespace(s), the pods in the namespaces have their containers
checked and if a named port is matched a Security Group rule with
a 'remote_ip_prefixes' field pointing to that pod is created.

Change-Id: If1eddc3e6cc4884ca53e81e4f87b5fae80fed70e
Closes-Bug: 1818983
"}, {'created': '2019-04-05 10:06:37.000000000', 'message': "Add support for text ports on Network Policy Spec

This commit adds support for Network Policies that define ports
with text in the ingress or egress section. It checks if the containers
in pods have their ports with the same name as the port defined in the

commit_message:
Add support for text ports on Network Policy Spec

This commit adds support for Network Policies that define ports
with text. In the case of ingress rule with named port, the pods
selected by NetworkPolicySpec's podSelector has its containers
verified to check for ports with same name. In case of egress rule
all the pods selected by the NetworkPolicyEgressRule's selector
have its containers verified to check if the containers ports
have the same name as the ones defined in policy rule ports.
If matched, a security Group rule with
a 'remote_ip_prefixes' field pointing to that pod is created.

Change-Id: If1eddc3e6cc4884ca53e81e4f87b5fae80fed70e
Closes-Bug: 1818983

commit_message:
Fix pyghmi path

Pyghmi was moved from openstack namespace to the x
namespace. As such the devstack plugin needs to match
up otherwise devstack fails in CI to clone as cloning
is blocked if not in the projects list... Which it is,
as x/pyghmi.

Change-Id: I87bdf65dd2dac189642d0af6def2d0ed155f3c00

commit_message:
Dropping the py35 testing

All the integration testing has been moved to
Bionic now[1] and py3.5 is not tested runtime for
Train or stable/stein[2].

As per below ML thread, we are good to drop the py35
testing now:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/005097.html

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/004647.html
[2]
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/stein.html
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/train.html

Change-Id: I0df77203a507944b1b6bb5a18032d3b40bcd3a22

commit_message:
Update master for stable/stein

Add file to the reno documentation build to show release notes for
stable/stein.

Use pbr instruction to increment the minor version number
automatically so that master versions are higher than the versions on
stable/stein.

Change-Id: I2a01537456004bc0d9b88f5db91bcb227f62025c
Sem-Ver: feature

commit_message:
Migrate ansible-lint to pre-commit

* Kept old specific linter tox targets for backwards compatibility,
  so developer can easily run a single linter if desired.
* Reused tox linters virtualenvs to avoid wasting space
* Moved linter config to their official location which enables
  developer to call them in any way he wants (like his IDE)
* tools/validate-files.py has been updated to check out all the custom
  library files coming from the new validation framework.

Change-Id: I4118200e6862763a0e9dac921dc7c42019224d12
Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud <gchamoul@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-19 08:12:34.000000000', 'message': 'Fix Jinja2's default filter usage

The default() filter provided by Jinja2 treats the special class
Undefined differently from False-y Python values. By default, default()
will only return its first argument if the prior expression evaluates to
Undefined. The second boolean parameter asks the function to also accept
Python False-y values as undefined and return the default value.

In our case, when we retrieve the variable "container_cli" from the file
'undercloud.conf' or from the inventory, it may not be present and the
default function does not work since the variable "container_cli" is
Undefined or set to an empty string.

Change-Id: Id44338a3b6ecea16c3a0bf7eb1e7c0b431e69f95
Implements: blueprint validation-framework
Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud <gchamoul@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Fix Jinja2's default filter usage

The default() filter provided by Jinja2 treats the special class
Undefined differently from False-y Python values. By default, default()
will only return its first argument if the prior expression evaluates to
Undefined. The second boolean parameter asks the function to also accept
Python False-y values as undefined and return the default value.

In our case, when we retrieve the variable "container_cli" from the file
'undercloud.conf' or from the inventory, it may not be present and the
default function does not work since the variable "container_cli" is
Undefined or set to an empty string.

Change-Id: Id44338a3b6ecea16c3a0bf7eb1e7c0b431e69f95
Implements: blueprint validation-framework
Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud <gchamoul@redhat.com>

Train or stable/stein[2].

testing now:

commit_message:
Switch to Debian Stretch for building DIB images

It seems that Jessie is no longer supported, and its backports repo
is no longer available, hence all DIB jobs fail.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/653453/
Change-Id: I7973c8da057a678e6285ecc9418a4862bc1d3feb

commit_message:
Swap special CI jobs from xenial to bionic

The neutron role currently tests a whole bunch of network setups
on xenial, which is no longer supported for OSA since Rocky. Switch
these jobs over to bionic

Change-Id: I37d4bb79f4441932008a0f43c4ab3dead5fc96d6

commit_message:
Make python mistralclient readme better

Mark command line as code blocks to prevent validation errors.

Conflicts:
    Updated .zuul.yaml to skip code testing on rst file changes

Change-Id: Ic42f6fa3e6a83cb0c4c3a5a324611411d2df7a1e
(cherry picked from commit 316db62e9c1038a636e8a66997c35479fa233847)

The ipxe file can have different extensions based on the distro.

'}]
commit_message:
Fixing ipxe file not found in Centos job

The ipxe file can have different extensions based on the distro.
Changing from .pxe to generic extension should cover them all.

Change-Id: I6da5bf86a022315861d140029ce25321a5b57469

messages:
[{'account_id': 13686, 'date': '2019-04-23 13:39:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 13686, 'date': '2019-04-23 14:00:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Patch Set 1 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 20805, 'date': '2019-04-23 18:44:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

So the deletion of the ceph keyring makes me a bit nervous. I'd like a second pair of eyes on this.

Can you confirm the key is kept on the ceph side of the relation? In case we need to re-connect.

Otherwise, the code looks good."}, {'account_id': 13686, 'date': '2019-04-24 05:32:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

The key deletion is a unit-local cleanup action and replicates existing charm behavior. The keys are kept safe on the Ceph Monitor.'}, {'account_id': 20634, 'date': '2019-04-24 08:07:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
WIP: Added no-wait for ovs operations

for unclear reason sometimes ovs[1] does not
return after removing ports from the bridge.

[1] # ovs-vsctl --version
    ovs-vsctl (Open vSwitch) 2.10.1
    DB Schema 7.16.1
    at /etc/redhat-release

    CentOS Linux release 7.6.1810 (Core)
    Linux r-dcs04 3.10.0-957.el7.x86_64 #1 SMP Thu Nov 8 23:39:32 UTC 2018 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux

Change-Id: I22e92a627eeab739c2aa3d3f7254d710c1c7e309

Change-Id: I327f77002bb752025bf158d6e675705f8034ed7d
'}]
commit_message:
Dropping the py35 testing

All the integration testing has been moved to
Bionic now[1] and py3.5 is not tested runtime for
Train or stable/stein[2].

As per below ML thread, we are good to drop the py35
testing now:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/005097.html

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/004647.html
[2]
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/stein.html
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/train.html

Change-Id: I327f77002bb752025bf158d6e675705f8034ed7d

commit_message:
Remove docs for --allow-multiattach

This flag has been deprecated since Queens and is beinge removed from
python-cinderclient. We should only now state the supported multiattach
configuration using volume type extra specs.

Change-Id: Ic0156dc5abb15a04ba5c6e0900177aa6c22d7940
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-17 19:00:34.000000000', 'message': 'libvirt: set device address tag only if setting disk unit

In Pike, we began setting disk unit values manually for the
'virtio-scsi' controller model in order to allow up to 256 devices [1].
We do this by setting the disk unit of the address tag manually for the
guest config. If we do not set the address tag manually, libvirt would
autogenerate it for us.

A problem occurs when a user has a SCSI disk that is a volume or isn't
using the 'virtio-scsi' controller model because we're not guarding our
manual setting of the address tag in the guest config by the disk unit,
in addition to the SCSI bus. This means that for a SCSI volume, we
generate an address tag like '<address type="drive" controller="0"/>'
for any SCSI volume, so a user with more than one device will get the
following error when they try to boot an instance:

  Failed to start libvirt guest: libvirtError: unsupported
    configuration: Found duplicate drive address for disk with target name
    'sda' controller='0' bus='0' target='0' unit='0'

This updates the conditionals to only manually set the address tag if
the bus is SCSI _and_ the disk unit has been specified. Otherwise, let
libvirt autogenerate the address tag and take care of avoiding
collisions.

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1686116

Closes-Bug: #1792077

Change-Id: Iefab05e84ccc0bf8f15bdbbf515a290d282dbc5d
(cherry picked from commit 48fd81648a7cadf2d147a6beabac067c28b288b0)
(cherry picked from commit 7500c1910cf1cbe16ee48028b67aa919160f44da)
(cherry picked from commit 72fdbb1b045b01d1ce6907066032ffdf5f3fae73)

following error when they try to boot an instance:

  Failed to start libvirt guest: libvirtError: unsupported

    'sda' controller='0' bus='0' target='0' unit='0'

This updates the conditionals to only manually set the address tag if
the bus is SCSI _and_ the disk unit has been specified. Otherwise, let

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1686116

Closes-Bug: #1792077

Change-Id: Iefab05e84ccc0bf8f15bdbbf515a290d282dbc5d

commit_message:
libvirt: set device address tag only if setting disk unit

In Pike, we began setting disk unit values manually for the
'virtio-scsi' controller model in order to allow up to 256 devices [1].
We do this by setting the disk unit of the address tag manually for the
guest config. If we do not set the address tag manually, libvirt would
autogenerate it for us.

A problem occurs when a user has a SCSI disk that is a volume or isn't
using the 'virtio-scsi' controller model because we're not guarding our
manual setting of the address tag in the guest config by the disk unit,
in addition to the SCSI bus. This means that for a SCSI volume, we
generate an address tag like '<address type="drive" controller="0"/>'
for any SCSI volume, so a user with more than one device will get the
following error when they try to boot an instance:

  Failed to start libvirt guest: libvirtError: unsupported
    configuration: Found duplicate drive address for disk with target name
    'sda' controller='0' bus='0' target='0' unit='0'

This updates the conditionals to only manually set the address tag if
the bus is SCSI _and_ the disk unit has been specified. Otherwise, let
libvirt autogenerate the address tag and take care of avoiding
collisions.

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1686116

Closes-Bug: #1792077

Change-Id: Iefab05e84ccc0bf8f15bdbbf515a290d282dbc5d
(cherry picked from commit 48fd81648a7cadf2d147a6beabac067c28b288b0)
(cherry picked from commit 7500c1910cf1cbe16ee48028b67aa919160f44da)
(cherry picked from commit 8703282508954596e1d041340878c636693d8f5f)

Add a new parameter to undercloud.conf to disable the container
healthchecks.

The parameter is: container_healthcheck_disabled and it's False by
default, so the healthchecks are enabled by default.

Depends-On: Id8d7e21d58cf5ab155404db597d96665b94d7c2a

"}]
commit_message:
undercloud: wire ContainerHealthcheckDisabled

Add a new parameter to undercloud.conf to disable the container
healthchecks.

The parameter is: container_healthcheck_disabled and it's False by
default, so the healthchecks are enabled by default.

Depends-On: Id8d7e21d58cf5ab155404db597d96665b94d7c2a
Change-Id: Icebfad41cc286a2e209511c147d74f1a933c66a2
(cherry picked from commit cefb2df8c39fc0c23ef1787c0b7e6191288fb096)

the openstack-infra. The other git urls will work through the
redirect, but cleaning them up is just nicer.

This removes two comments that reference files that no longer

Also, fix some random use of github for cloning openstack repos,
since the github mirror is best-effort only.

commit_message:
Update links for opendev

The most important bits are updating shade references to remove
the openstack-infra. The other git urls will work through the
redirect, but cleaning them up is just nicer.

This removes two comments that reference files that no longer
exist due to config generation.

Also, fix some random use of github for cloning openstack repos,
since the github mirror is best-effort only.

Change-Id: I55a1d9db940cf5fa2c35421db7add015ae334563
Needed-By: https://review.opendev.org/654056

commit_message:
update "auth_url" in document

With the removal of the keystone v2 API, keystone
can be run on the same port "5000" for all interfaces.
for more information.see [0][1]
[0]https://docs.openstack.org/keystone/latest/contributor/http-api.html
[1]https://docs.openstack.org/keystone/latest/install/keystone-install-rdo.html#install-and-configure-components

[{'created': '2019-04-08 18:53:56.000000000', 'message': 'Fix build without git being installed in build env

Without git being installed, the old (deprecated) pbr integration fails
with

  Warning, treated as error:
  Cannot find git top directory, assuming "."

we did not notice that in the SUSE CI because there was a local hack,
but an actual openSUSE build fails. by switching to sphinx-build
we can avoid this problem, which is more consistent with the rest
of the spec files anyway.

commit_message:
Fix build without git being installed in build env

Without git being installed, the old (deprecated) pbr integration fails
with

  Warning, treated as error:
  Cannot find git top directory, assuming "."

we did not notice that in the SUSE CI because there was a local hack,
but an actual openSUSE build fails. by switching to sphinx-build
we can avoid this problem, which is more consistent with the rest
of the spec files anyway.

Change-Id: I2dced5316da56e580dddc78d9706ab7562c9257b

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-22 12:48:50.000000000', 'message': 'Use oslo_messaging_rpc_port for nova rpc healthchecks

With 405366fa32583e88c34417e5f46fa574ed8f4e98 the parameters RpcPort,
RpcUserName, RpcPassword and RpcUseSSL got deprecated and
nova::rabbitmq_port removed. As a result the healtcheck get called with
null parameter and fail.
We now get the global_config_settings from RabbitMQService and use
oslo_messaging_rpc_port for the healthcheck.

Change-Id: I1849926b1d6256de5f4d677de5a9b34d78aad5d0
Closes-Bug: #1824805
(cherry picked from commit 8ff04029f5bc4cc2db4b3575229ce7bafb4eb358)
'}]
commit_message:
Use oslo_messaging_rpc_port for nova rpc healthchecks

With 405366fa32583e88c34417e5f46fa574ed8f4e98 the parameters RpcPort,
RpcUserName, RpcPassword and RpcUseSSL got deprecated and
nova::rabbitmq_port removed. As a result the healtcheck get called with
null parameter and fail.
We now get the global_config_settings from RabbitMQService and use
oslo_messaging_rpc_port for the healthcheck.

Change-Id: I1849926b1d6256de5f4d677de5a9b34d78aad5d0
Closes-Bug: #1824805
(cherry picked from commit 8ff04029f5bc4cc2db4b3575229ce7bafb4eb358)

commit_message:
[Telemetry] final releases for pike

This is a procedural review to tag a final release for each deliverables ; and

It's possible that the release isn't needed (for example if there are no code
changes sine the previous release, sadly that's non-trivial to detect en masse.

If you are the PTL or release liaison for this team please +1 this review
if it is ready or -1 and take over the review to correct mistakes.

Change-Id: Ic0f41662bb9c891c9dd468ac4ea36248301c8d19

commit_message:
[keystone] create pike-em tag against final releases

This is a procedural review to transition pike into extended maintenance by
creating the pike-em tag

It's possible that the release isn't needed (for example if there are no code
changes sine the previous release, sadly that's non-trivial to detect en masse.

If you are the PTL or release liaison for this team please +1 this review
if it is ready or -1 and take over the review to correct mistakes.

Change-Id: I0926338c9eaa05a646e1f61916de154a380cc6c5

[{'created': '2019-02-26 16:40:42.000000000', 'message': 'Improve CinderFixtureNewAttachFlow

This does a few things:

1. Add a attachment_ids_for_instance() method which
   can be used to get all volume attachment IDs for an
   instance which is useful in tests that need to make
   sure attachments are tracked and cleaned up properly,
   i.e. to make sure nothing leaked.

2. Implements the attachment_complete method in order to
   fail if code is trying to complete an attachment that
   does not exist.

3. Adds logging in the various attachment CRUD methods to
   aid in debugging test failures.

Change-Id: If6a36d23768877bfa820ed44b610bfb113df5464

commit_message:
Improve CinderFixtureNewAttachFlow

This does three things:

1. Implements the attachment_complete method in order to
   fail if code is trying to complete an attachment that
   does not exist.

2. Adds logging in the various attachment CRUD methods to
   aid in debugging test failures.

3. Mirrors the method signature for is_microversion_supported
   to make sure code is at least calling it properly.

Change-Id: If6a36d23768877bfa820ed44b610bfb113df5464

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-06 00:53:28.000000000', 'message': "Fix ProviderUsageBaseTestCase._run_periodics for multi-cell

The _run_periodics() method is using a non-targeted context
when running the update_available_resource method on all
computes created in the test. For tests that use multiple
cells where the compute services/nodes are created in multiple
cells, the periodic running on the non-cell1 services would
not find the ComputeNode because the context is not targeted.
By default, the CellDatabase fixture is targeted at cell1 in
the base TestCase._setup_cells() method, so when querying the
database without a targeted context, it will look in cell1
which could be wrong if you're trying to update resources in
cell2.

This fixes the issue by simply getting the CellMapping per host
and targeting the context before calling update_available_resource.

Change-Id: Ieeac3bdb82a23179ff6c652b2e9e05a3f6bc9032
